entries.title: Kotlin Coroutines book premiere
entries.author: Kasia Kt. Academy

content.value:
Hello, dear readers! 🤩

📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚📚

Long-time no see.
We were very busy preparing for the book premiere and new workshops.

Now we are back and speaking of which…
we are so glad to announce the Kotlin Coroutines book premiere written by Marcin Moskala. 🥳

We have a special offer for our subscribers!
⬇ 25% off the normal price for the newest book by Marcin Moskala:

Kotlin Coroutines. Deep Dive.

✂ This link gives you a special price for Kotlin Coroutines ebook on Leanpub!

Wanna know more before buying? 😎
Sure! 🤩
We prepared two promos. Written version as well as video for those, who would like to see the person standing behind this book. 💎

No one would better explain the writing process than the author. 😍

Find out for whom Kotlin Coroutines was created and what this book is about in the article written by Marcin Moskala.

Prefer watching? 👀
Wanna meet the author? ✍
Go for it. 😎
Check out our movie promo 👇

📕📗📘📕📗📘📕📗📘📕📗📘📕📗📘📕📗📘📕📗📘📕📗📘📕📗📘

We wish you a pleasant reading 🤩
Hope to see you on our upcoming workshops! 👀

If there is anything you want to inform us about, let us know by replying to this email! 💌

Stay tuned! 👌
Kt. Academy Team

www: kt.academy
Blog: blog.kotlin-academy.com
Twitter EN: @KtDotAcademy
Twitter PL: @ktdotacademyPL
FB: @KtDotAcademy
LinkedIn: @Kt. Academy

Kotlin Coroutines book premiere 🥳 was originally published in Kt. Academy on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

entries.title: So in love with coding: 2 Kotlin Coroutines Articles & Kobby Plugin Article & Funny Programming

title_detail.value: So in love with coding: 2 Kotlin Coroutines Articles & Kobby Plugin Article & Funny Programming

entries.author: Kasia Kt. Academy

content.value:
Hi there programmers! 🤗

💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗💗
Recently we have celebrated Valentine’s Day!
We wish you lots of love ….
especially for coding!

Below you can find a brief list of today’s newsletter content:

Kotlin Coroutines-Flow articles written by Marcin Moskała:
👉 Collecting values on flow: fold and scan
👉 Flattening flow: flatMapConcat, flatMapMerge and flatMapLatest

Articles are the parts from the Kotlin Coroutine book. You can find the early access here. 📖

Kobby Plugin article written by Dmitry Ermakov:
👉 How to generate Kotlin DSL Client by GraphQL schema

✳ Dmitry contacted us and we republished his article.
Wanna be like Dmitry?
We are still open to new authors.
More info on our Medium 📝

Offtop funny content article written by Marcin Moskała to make you laugh:
👉 Funny programming videos

We wanna sing:
😂 “I feel it in my fingers, I feel it in my toes
CODE is all around me and so the feeling grows” 😂

Enjoy! 🙃

Let’s learn how can we accumulate flow values with fold and scan. 👇

Collecting values on flow: fold and scan

🔻 This is a chapter from the Kotlin Coroutines book. You can find Early Access on LeanPub.

Let’s learn how can we flatMap flow with flatMapConcat, flatMapMerge, and flatMapLatest.

👉 Flattening flow: flatMapConcat, flatMapMerge and flatMapLatest

🔻 This is a chapter from the Kotlin Coroutines book. You can find Early Access on LeanPub.

Introducing the Kobby Plugin — a code generator of Kotlin GraphQL Client. Let’s try it out! Sounds interesting, then read the article written by Dmitry Ermakov. 👇

How to generate Kotlin DSL Client by GraphQL schema

📹 We, developers, created our own subculture. No wonder, there are over 24 million of us worldwide. We share similar problems and frustrations. Among us, there are many musicians and other kinds of artists. No wonder our community produces some funny video or a comic from time to time. In this article, Marcin Moskała collected his favourite videos.

Funny programming videos

Only 2 weeks left to the open Kotlin Coroutines Workshop conducted by Marcin Moskała 🤩

📅: 03–04.03.2022
⏲: 9:00–17:00 CET (GMT+1)
💰: 300 EUR pp
🔤: EN

Check the details and register here 👇

Kotlin Coroutines (kt.academy)

💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝💝

Code is in the air! 💝
That’s all from us for today 🙂

If there is anything you want to inform us about, let us know by replying to this email! 💌

Stay tuned! 👌
Kt. Academy Team

www: kt.academy
Blog: blog.kotlin-academy.com
Twitter EN: @KtDotAcademy
Twitter PL: @ktdotacademyPL
FB: @KtDotAcademy
LinkedIn: @Kt. Academy

So in love with coding: 2 Kotlin Coroutines Articles & Kobby Plugin Article & Funny Programming 💘 was originally published in Kt. Academy on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

entries.title: 2 Kotlin Coroutines Flow Articles & Android Article & Coroutines Open Workshop

title_detail.value: 2 Kotlin Coroutines Flow Articles & Android Article & Coroutines Open Workshop

entries.author: Kasia Kt. Academy

content.value:
Hi there Code-lovers 🤗

A new month means new energy and new ideas. We are entering into February with great news! We are currently working on new workshops:
🤖 machine learning, neural networks, and AI 🧠
Isn’t it exciting? 😀
More details soon, stay tuned 📣

Future sounds promising! 🤩
Below you can find a brief list of today’s newsletter content:

Kotlin Coroutines — Flow articles written by Marcin Moskała:
👉 Flow lifecycle operations
👉 Combining flows: merge, zip, and combine

More articles you can find on our website. 📃

Android article written by Mustafa Yiğit:
👉 Say Hello 👋 to Jetpack Compose and Compare with XML

More Mustafa’s and other authors’ articles you can find on our Medium 📝

Ready? 🏃‍♂️🏃‍♀️

Let’s learn about lifecycle operations, controlling context, and handling exceptions in flow. 👇

Flow lifecycle operations

Let’s learn how can we transform two flows into one, with merge, zip, and combine.

👉 Combining flows: merge, zip, and combine

Mustafa Yiğit will try to explain what’s in the box for Jetpack Compose and what is the difference between compose and XML based design. Let’s dive into the UI development in Android without XML. 👇

Say Hello 👋 to Jetpack Compose and Compare with XML

One month left to the open Kotlin Coroutines Workshop conducted by Marcin Moskała 🤩

📅: 03–04.03.2022
⏲: 9:00–17:00 CET (GMT+1)
💰: 300 EUR pp
🔤: EN

Check the details and register here 👇

Kotlin Coroutines (kt.academy)

📘📙📘📙📘📙📘📙📘📙📘📙📘📙📘📙📘📙📘📙📘📙📘📙📘📙📘📙

That’s all from us for today, thank you 🙂

If there is anything you want to inform us about, let us know by replying to this email! 💌

Stay tuned! 👌
Kt. Academy Team

www: kt.academy
Blog: blog.kotlin-academy.com
Twitter EN: @KtDotAcademy
Twitter PL: @ktdotacademyPL
FB: @KtDotAcademy
LinkedIn: @Kt. Academy

2 Kotlin Coroutines Flow Articles & Android Article & Coroutines Open Workshop 🏆 was originally published in Kt. Academy on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

entries.title: How to generate Kotlin DSL Client by GraphQL schema

title_detail.value: How to generate Kotlin DSL Client by GraphQL schema

entries.author: Dmitry Ermakov

content.value:
Introducing the Kobby Plugin — a code generator of Kotlin GraphQL Client

On the one hand, the GraphQL schema uniquely defines the data model and the available operations of the service that implements it. On the other hand, Kotlin provides amazing opportunities for creating your own domain-specific languages (DSL). This way, you can write a domain-specific language to interact with your GraphQL service according to the published GraphQL schema. But writing such a code manually is Sisyphean labor. This is where the Kobby Plugin comes in, which can parse your service’s GraphQL schema and generate a client DSL for interaction. Let’s try it out!

The source code for the examples in this article is available in Kobby Gradle Tutorial and Kobby Maven Tutorial.

What will we get in the end?

If you are too lazy to read the whole article…

Query

https://medium.com/media/e40b8c3ef4c62e3e7d9168767b2fa292/href

Mutation

https://medium.com/media/1ba2bec8364da1939fa23e05a4f3cee6/href

Subscription

https://medium.com/media/425b555882d7f11f5cd1ad609cdde709/href

Kobby Plugin setup

In the beginning was the Word…

But we will start with a schema of our service. By default, the Kobby Plugin looks for a GraphQL schema in files with graphqls extensions in the project resources. For the sake of simplicity, we will place our schema in a single file named cinema.graphqls:

https://medium.com/media/f64c75ea428a7f0b4eb485daad7a0fdb/href

This simple schema will allow us to try out all kinds of GraphQL operations — queries, mutations, and subscriptions.

Next, we have to configure the plugin. For Gradle projects it looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/b18e5bdd00cb732d0422fd6553f4c7e1/href

For Maven projects, this does not look so elegant:

https://medium.com/media/e6673b3c0b0309887b89e82e88451ac8/href

There are explicit and implicit ways to configure the plugin. We used the implicit way by adding dependencies to the Jackson and Ktor libraries. The Kobby Plugin not only scans resources for schema files but also analyzes project dependencies. If Jackson is present in the dependencies, then the plugin adds Jackson annotations to the generated DTO classes to ensure JSON serialization. If Ktor is present in the project dependencies, then the plugin generates a default DSL adapter. We’ll talk about adapters in the next section.

Instantiate DSL Context

We have configured our plugin. Now we have to generate a DSL according to our schema. Run gradle build for Gradle or mvn compile for Maven and the plugin will find the cinema.graphqls file and generate a DSL based on it:

The plugin will create the cinema.kt file with the cinemaContextOf builder function that instantiates the CinemaContext interface — the entry point of the generated DSL:

https://medium.com/media/d2dde37955f7c94f3daa4114ad210154/href

We have to pass an instance of the CinemaAdapter interface to the builder function to create the context. What is an adapter? The DSL context, generated by the Kobby Plugin, knows nothing about the transport layer and GraphQL communication protocol. The context implementation just builds the query and passes it to the adapter. And the adapter has to do all the dirty work — send the query to the server, and receive and deserialize the response. You can write your own adapter implementation or use the default adapter generated by the plugin.

We will use the default adapter. It uses Ktor to execute GraphQL queries and mutations over HTTP and to establish subscription sessions over WebSocket:

https://medium.com/media/68b80809c3bd69e8fab33a7eee2417d1/href

Executing Queries

We are ready to execute our first query. Let’s try to find a film with actors by ID. In GraphQL, this query looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/55699cbd99b393d532e83763774934df/href

In Kotlin, it looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/5c13e4679815e07740245251f3b135a6/href

The context.query is suspending function, and does not block the current thread. What do we get as a result of executing the query? In GraphQL, the result is JSON that looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/7b343c938ed065791ba80938da87046f/href

To navigate through the result, the plugin generates “entity” interfaces that look like this:

https://medium.com/media/334ac21b2a1a696854090b0014abbf00/href

The context.query function returns an instance of the Query entity, so the navigation through the result looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/6e4469981c8088d428ec62c865ba261c/href

Executing Mutations

Let’s create a new movie. In GraphQL, the mutation looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/c50dbd01be2155d39e00b45495d646d2/href

And we’ll get the result as a JSON that looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/d0ef3077cacf9546c1ad906c3bee99a2/href

In Kotlin, this mutation looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/690c6a75662470accd3d1cf8e9d1bda1/href

The context.mutation function returns an instance of the Mutation entity interface and also is suspending function. So, our mutation does not block the current thread.

Establishing Subscriptions

Let’s subscribe for new films notifications. In GraphQL, the subscription looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/643a888a3e5a7722de148280e7ccbbfc/href

With this subscription, we will receive JSON messages that look like this:

https://medium.com/media/465ac18cd25d0725b61bb2084b65acb0/href

The semantics of the subscription operation in Kotlin is different from the semantics of the query and mutation operations. While the query and mutation just send a request and receive a response, the subscription creates a long-lived session to listen to incoming messages. So, we have to create an asynchronous listener to receive incoming messages:

https://medium.com/media/f11f5f2c786219d8fa7af3905bfbe830/href

Don’t worry, we are not blocking the thread in an infinite loop, because the subscribe function and the receive function are suspending functions.

The lifetime of the subscription session is the same as the execution time of the subscribe function. When we enter the subscribe function, a session is created, and when we exit it, the session is destroyed.

The receive function returns an instance of the Subscription entity interface for each incoming message.

What have I not covered in this article?

  • I haven’t covered how to map scalars defined in a schema to Kotlin datatypes.
  • I haven’t talked about how the plugin works with abstract data types.
  • I haven’t covered how to customize the generated DSL using GraphQL directives.
  • I haven’t talked about how the plugin supports server-side development.

And most importantly, I didn’t talk about how to use Kotlin extension functions to turn the generated DSL into a rich domain model on steroids. Perhaps I will cover this in future articles.

How to generate Kotlin DSL Client by GraphQL schema was originally published in Kt. Academy on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

To navigate through the result, the plugin generates “entity” interfaces that look like this:

https://medium.com/media/334ac21b2a1a696854090b0014abbf00/href

The context.query function returns an instance of the Query entity, so the navigation through the result looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/6e4469981c8088d428ec62c865ba261c/href

Executing Mutations

Let’s create a new movie. In GraphQL, the mutation looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/c50dbd01be2155d39e00b45495d646d2/href

And we’ll get the result as a JSON that looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/d0ef3077cacf9546c1ad906c3bee99a2/href

In Kotlin, this mutation looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/690c6a75662470accd3d1cf8e9d1bda1/href

The context.mutation function returns an instance of the Mutation entity interface and also is suspending function. So, our mutation does not block the current thread.

Establishing Subscriptions

Let’s subscribe for new films notifications. In GraphQL, the subscription looks like this:

https://medium.com/media/643a888a3e5a7722de148280e7ccbbfc/href

With this subscription, we will receive JSON messages that look like this:

https://medium.com/media/465ac18cd25d0725b61bb2084b65acb0/href

The semantics of the subscription operation in Kotlin is different from the semantics of the query and mutation operations. While the query and mutation just send a request and receive a response, the subscription creates a long-lived session to listen to incoming messages. So, we have to create an asynchronous listener to receive incoming messages:

https://medium.com/media/f11f5f2c786219d8fa7af3905bfbe830/href

Don’t worry, we are not blocking the thread in an infinite loop, because the subscribe function and the receive function are suspending functions.

The lifetime of the subscription session is the same as the execution time of the subscribe function. When we enter the subscribe function, a session is created, and when we exit it, the session is destroyed.

The receive function returns an instance of the Subscription entity interface for each incoming message.

What have I not covered in this article?

  • I haven’t covered how to map scalars defined in a schema to Kotlin datatypes.
  • I haven’t talked about how the plugin works with abstract data types.
  • I haven’t covered how to customize the generated DSL using GraphQL directives.
  • I haven’t talked about how the plugin supports server-side development.

And most importantly, I didn’t talk about how to use Kotlin extension functions to turn the generated DSL into a rich domain model on steroids. Perhaps I will cover this in future articles.

How to generate Kotlin DSL Client by GraphQL schema was originally published in Kt. Academy on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

entries.title: Say Hello  to Jetpack Compose and Compare with XML

title_detail.value: Say Hello  to Jetpack Compose and Compare with XML

entries.author: Mustafa Yiğit

content.value:
Introduction

Hi everyone 👋 I will try to explain Jetpack Compose Fundamentals and Why should I use Jetpack Compose. Jetpack Compose is important because it is a new way of building modern UI in Android. Let’s dive into the UI development in Android without XML.

In my opinion, Jetpack Compose is the future of Android UI development and we must adopt fastly.

What is Jetpack Compose?

Jetpack Compose is Android’s modern toolkit for building native UI. It simplifies and accelerates UI development on Android - Google

Jetpack Compose is a modern toolkit that allows us to build our screens in a declarative approach writing less code. Android UI Development is now more powerful and more decoupled.

Before Jetpack Compose, we were using XML layouts to build the native UI. We had a very dependent structure when we build the screens with XML. Also, fragments are very heavy components for the UI. Jetpack Compose allows us to build the same UI with a declarative UI approach and with less code.

Why should I use Jetpack Compose?

In my opinion, it’s more than easy from XML and Kotlin ❤️

If we look technically:

  • Declarative UI is cleaner, readable, and performant than Imperative UI.
  • Compose allows you to do more with less code compared to XML.
  • Compose is Intuitive. This means that you just need to tell Compose what you want to show the user.
  • Compose is compatible with all your existing code: you can call Compose code from Views and Views from Compose. Also integrated with many Jetpack Libraries.
  • Compose improves your build time and APK size.

XML Design vs Jetpack Compose

Composition — Recomposition — State Management

Each composables has a initial compositon. Initial composition runs only when we see a view at first time in screen.

Composables can hold a state and re-run on state changes. This is called Recomposition.

Atomic Design

In Compose, component inheritance is implemented with functions, because composables are functions. A composable function can only be called with in another composable. As we write smaller composables, we get a more flexible component structure.

XML vs Jetpack Compose with Code Samples

1. Basic UI Components

Now let’s build the same view using Xml and Jetpack Compose and look at the differences on the code side.
Here is the target view structure:

Build with Xml

https://medium.com/media/6d80eef191694147abeb5c9dafd9de48/href

Build with Jetpack Compose

https://medium.com/media/ea8c90e50b9246930ff2cdb80979d048/href

2. List Items

Build with Xml

We need a few file/class for showing a list in screen with Xml:

  1. adapter_item_list.xml
  2. ListItemAdapter.kt
  3. ListItemViewHolder (inner class)
  4. Populate activity/fragment

Build with Jetpack Compose

We need only LazyColumn for showing list items in screen. No needed adapter class or item design xml file. We can describe item design in item/items scope.

https://medium.com/media/485323a678a8ef94168f1af7ebabfa29/href

State Management

“State in an app is any value that can change over time.”- Google

Compose is declarative so the only way to update it is by calling with different arguments.

Initial Composition: creation of a Composition by running composables the first time.
Recomposition: Re-running composables to update the Composition when data (state) changes.

Store a data with remember:

val data by remember { mutableStateOf(INITIAL_VALUE) }

If you want to keep data when configuration changes, you shold store data with rememberSaveable:

var tite by rememberSaveable { mutableStateOf("") }
Text(
    text = title,
    modifier = Modifier.padding(bottom = 10.dp),
    style = MaterialTheme.typography.h5
)

Navigation

Everything is composable, even navigation. We need a NavHost and Screens. Every screen should have a route.

Route: A string that defines the path your composable. Each destination should have a unique route.
NavGraphBuilder.composable: A function for bindind your composable using unique route with navigation graph.

Here is a composable function for creating NavHost:

  • MainActivity.kt:
@Composable
fun AppNavigation() {
    val navController = rememberNavController()
    NavHost(
        navController = navController,
        startDestination = NavScreen.getStartDestination()
    ) {
        composable(NavScreen.Home.route) { HomeScreen(navController) }
        composable(NavScreen.Explore.route) { ExploreScreen(navController) }
    }
}
sealed class NavScreen(val route: String) {
    object Home : NavScreen("home")
    object Explore : NavScreen("explore")
    companion object {
        fun getStartDestination() = Home.route
    }
}
  • HomeScreen.kt:
@Composable
fun HomeScreen(
    navController: NavController = rememberNavController(),
    homeViewModel: HomeViewModel = viewModel()
) {
    Column(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center
    ) {
        Text(text = homeViewModel.getTitle())
        Button(
            onClick = { navController.navigate(NavScreen.Explore.route) },
        ) {
            Text(text = "Go to Explore screen")
        }
    }
}
  • ExploreScreen.kt
@Composable
fun ExploreScreen(
    navController: NavController = rememberNavController(),
    exploreViewModel: ExploreViewModel = viewModel()
) {
    Column(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
        horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
        verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center
    ) {
        Text(text = exploreViewModel.getTitle())
        Button(
            onClick = { navController.navigateUp() },
        ) {
            Text(text = "back to previous screen")
        }
    }
}

Conclusion

https://medium.com/media/cdc780cb2eaa529a2ae0ae9b81575ef2/href

And we’re done. In this article, I wanted to explain what’s in the box for Jetpack Compose and what is the difference between compose and XML based design.

To me, Jetpack Compose is a revolution of Android UI development. Less code and more understandable code, declarative UI approach, managing state, and more. In addition, it can work directly with the jetpack libraries.

I hope this article was helpful. if so you can leave claps 👏 👏 If you catch a wrong, please leave me a message.

Twitter & Linkedin & Github

Resources

  • Github
  • Other Sources

https://developer.android.com/jetpack/compose/why-adopt

https://developer.android.com/jetpack/compose/ergonomics

Jetpack Compose — Before and after

https://medium.com/androiddevelopers/jetpack-compose-before-and-after-8b43ba0b7d4f

https://developer.android.com/jetpack/compose/mental-model

Subthreads

  • Composition / Recomposition
  • State Management
  • Remember / Remember Saveable / Immutable
  • Animations
  • Side Effects
  • Declarative UI

Say Hello 👋 to Jetpack Compose and Compare with XML was originally published in Kt. Academy on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

entries.title: Kt Academy 4th Bday & 2 Kotlin Coroutines Articles & Authors Wanted

title_detail.value: Kt Academy 4th Bday & 2 Kotlin Coroutines Articles & Authors Wanted

entries.author: Kasia Kt. Academy

content.value:
Hello, dear readers! 🤩

🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰

We are celebrating our 4th Bday! 🥳

On this occasion, we have a special offer for our subscribers!
⬇ 30% off the normal price for the upcoming workshop:

the open Kotlin Coroutines (EN) workshop conducted by Marcin Moskala! 🤩

📅 03–04.03.2022 👇

Kotlin Coroutines (kt.academy)

✂ Write❗Bday30❗in the “additional info” field.

✴ Offer valid until 31.01.2022. Don’t miss it! 🏃‍♀️

📝 Today we are going on with Kotlin Coroutines articles written by Marcin Moskała.
Here is a brief summary of them 👇

👉 Flow building
👉 Testing Kotlin Coroutines

More articles you can find on our website. 📃
Enjoy ⏬

Every flow needs to start somewhere.

So, let’s explore all the different flow builders. 👇

Flow building

🔻 This is a chapter from the Kotlin Coroutines book. You can find Early Access on LeanPub.

Coroutines introduced a new testing API in version 1.6. For instance, now we use runTest instead of runBlockingTest. 💪

With this change, we updated and completely reorganized the chapter of Kotlin Coroutines to better show common testing use-cases, and explain TestCoroutineScheduler, StandardTestDispatcher, and TestScope step by step.

👉 Testing Kotlin Coroutines

🔻 This is a chapter from the Kotlin Coroutines book. You can find Early Access on LeanPub.

✅ One more…
we know that you are fond of reading our articles, but… 📰
maybe you would be interested in writing something for Kt. Academy? ✒ Perhaps one day your article will be a part of our newsletter!
Isn’t it exciting? 🤩

📚 It does not matter if you are using Kotlin, Python, JavaScript, React, or TypeScript. Maybe you are great at Testing, Machine Learning, Android features, or other topics.

Let us know!

📧 If you have some idea for an article you want to write, just send an email to contact@kt.academy.

More details here
👉 Authors wanted

🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰 🍰

We can’t wait to read and publish your articles! 👏
Hope to see you on our workshops! 👀

If there is anything you want to inform us about, let us know by replying to this email! 💌

Stay tuned! 👌
Kt. Academy Team

www: kt.academy
Blog: blog.kotlin-academy.com
Twitter EN: @KtDotAcademy
Twitter PL: @ktdotacademyPL
FB: @KtDotAcademy
LinkedIn: @Kt. Academy

Kt Academy 4th Bday & 2 Kotlin Coroutines Articles & Authors Wanted 🔥 was originally published in Kt. Academy on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

entries.title: Write for us! Authors wanted!
entries.author: Halina Kt Academy

content.value:
Kt. Academy is widely recognized as a publication about programming.

Currently, it has:

  • over 10290 subscribers on Medium,
  • over 4870 emails on our newsletter;
  • around 3500 followers on Twitter (+ promotion from @MarcinMoskala — over 4860 users are following him).

You might know us from articles about Kotlin and Android, but we publish different topics as well. Our mission is to promote programming in general and simplify its learning. To serve this mission even better, we invite you to write articles with us.

Why?

Cooperation with us will help you to grow as a writer. You will get from us:

  • promotion on our publication and all our mediums,
  • feedback about the article,
  • technical proofing for the article content.

Good content will help you get more popular and reliable as an expert. With good promotion and our support, your voice will be heard. You will be able to speak in an important cause or to promote important ideas you believe in.

What?

It does not matter if you are using Kotlin, Python, JavaScript, React, or TypeScript. Maybe you are great at Testing, Machine Learning, Android features, or other topics. Let us know!

If you have some idea for an article you want to write, you can first ask us if we are interested. Just send an email to contact@kt.academy.

How?

You need a Medium account to write for KA. Then create a “New story” and start writing. Here is a small to-do list before the article can be considered as finished:

  • The article should have an image. Set it as a featured image by clicking it and pressing Shift+F. It should be either a photo taken by you or one of the free images. Alternatively, you can add a description with the link to the website where you found it.
  • Re-check and re-think your title. It is very important to make it interesting.
  • Check the grammar of the article using Grammarly (copy-paste the content there).
  • Check your article using Hemingway editor.

When it is all done, then click the “Share” button at the top of the screen and copy the link.

Send this link to contact@kt.academy with information that you want to publish your article on Kt. Academy. We will review it and answer you.

We wish you good writing :)

Write for us! Authors wanted! was originally published in Kt. Academy on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

entries.title: Summary of the Advent of Kotlin

title_detail.value: Summary of the Advent of Kotlin

entries.author: Kasia Kt. Academy

content.value:
Hello Kotliners!

ℹ️ This is a special, 4-weeks edition of our newsletter. It will contain only one, special topic — Advent of Kotlin.

Welcome to the summary of the Advent of Kotlin! 🎄

New Year has just started. We hope you liked our top seven picks of articles from 2021. Time to sum up the latest special event from the previous year’s #AdventOfKotlin challenge!

Thank you for your time and for solving our challenges 👏

Did you enjoy the tasks? 😍

Let us know, whether they were too hard and demanding or

… way too easy 😅 by replying to this email! 💌

We would like to remind you of all four tasks and give you the promised solutions. 🥇

👉 Advent of Kotlin: Week 1: JSON stringify and possible value parentheses
👉 Advent of Kotlin: Week 2: Tree algorithms
👉 Advent of Kotlin: Week 3: k-means clustering
👉 Advent of Kotlin: Week 4: JSON parsing

❗Advent of Kotlin: Solutions❗

Let’s start. Shall we? ⏬

This was a warm-up week. Instead of one complex challenge, there were two easy ones. Although they still gave you plenty of room to show good style :)

Advent of Kotlin: Week 1: JSON stringify and possible value parentheses👇

We continued with algorithmic problems, but this time we have been implementing some tree algorithms.

👉 Advent of Kotlin: Week 2: Tree algorithms

As artificial intelligence gets more and more important, this week we have been implementing an important AI algorithm: k-means clustering.

Advent of Kotlin: Week 3: k-means clustering 👇

We’ve started this advent with JSON stringify. The last week, we have done the opposite: JSON parsing.

Advent of Kotlin: Week 4: JSON parsing 👇

Finally, we promised you the solutions. 👌
Check out if you were right with your answers.

Below you can find them prepared by Marcin Moskala 👇

🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆🏆

Kt. Academy organized a contest for the best solutions.
According to the rules we announced the results on our Twitter!
Congrats 👏

One more…
soon we will be celebrating our birthday! 🎂🥳
Stay tuned! 👌

Kt. Academy Team

www: kt.academy
Blog: blog.kotlin-academy.com
Twitter EN: @KtDotAcademy
Twitter PL: @ktdotacademyPL
FB: @KtDotAcademy
LinkedIn: @Kt. Academy

Summary of the Advent of Kotlin🔥 was originally published in Kt. Academy on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

ℹ️ This is a special, 4-weeks edition of our newsletter. It will contain only one, special topic — Advent of Kotlin.

Welcome to the summary of the Advent of Kotlin! 🎄

entries.title: Best articles from 2021 from our blog & Happy New Year from Kt. Academy

title_detail.value: Best articles from 2021 from our blog & Happy New Year from Kt. Academy

entries.author: Kasia Kt. Academy

content.value:
Welcome! 🍾

How were your Christmas days? Did you rest properly? If so, we hope you are ready for the new experiences and challenges in the New Year. 💪

What about New Year’s Resolutions? Would you like to code more? ⌨

Anyway, we wish you that all your dreams come true, so
…. cheers to 2022! 🥂

To sum up the previous year we prepared something special for you! As we received many publications mostly about Kotlin and Android from different authors from all around the world, this time we are sharing the top seven articles from 2021, that you liked the most! 🏆

👉 It has never been easier to understand how to write Unit Tests on Android — Part 1
👉 Thinking functionally in Kotlin
👉 How to Secure Secrets 🔑 in Android — Android Security-01
👉 How to Secure Secrets 🔑 in Android (In-Depth) — Android Security-02
👉 Kotlin DSL, BuildSrc, Product Flavors, Flavor Icon and more
👉 How to build a GraphQL Gateway with Spring Boot and Kotlin
👉 Kotlin Collections vs Sequences in just 5 minutes

More articles you can find on our blog! 📃
Enjoy ⏬

In this article, Begüm Yazıcı will try to explain what are Unit tests, why should we write them, and how to write them.

It has never been easier to understand how to write Unit Tests on Android — Part 1 👇

In this article written by Kauserali Hafizji we’re going to work with Kotlin. Kotlin can be used anywhere where Java is used!

👉 Thinking functionally in Kotlin

Security is a key requirement while building an application that’s dealing with APIs, tokens received from a server, storing credentials in local DB, sending secure data onto the network, and many other scenarios.

Read the article How to Secure Secrets 🔑 in Android-Android Security-01 by Ali Azaz Alam

Part 1 👇

In google I/O 2019 Android team released its Security Cryptographic library named Jetpack Security to ease developers in building secured applications.

Secure Secrets 🔑 in Android using Jetpack Security (In-Depth) — Android Security-02 by Ali Azaz Alam

Part 2 👇

It’s really important to check dependencies and versions. Especially in applications with more than one module, we can prevent different dependency management in each module with the buildSrc module.
Let’s see, how we can do it in the article

Kotlin DSL, BuildSrc, Product Flavors, Flavor Icon and more by Mustafa Yiğit 👇

With Spring Boot + Kotlin + Coroutines + GraphQL-java-kickstart, you can build a GraphQL Gateway with a minimum of boilerplate.

To learn how to do it read the article written by Jean-Michel Fayard.

How to build a GraphQL Gateway with Spring Boot and Kotlin 👇

Let’s understand the difference between Kotlin Collections and Sequences in just 5 minutes ❗️ article written by Monika Kumar Jethani.

Kotlin Collections vs Sequences in just 5 minutes 👇

🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆🎆

Do you agree with our picks? What are your favourite articles from 2021? Let us know by replying to this email! 💌

All the best in 2022! 🍸 Stay tuned! 👌
Kt. Academy Team

www: kt.academy
Blog: blog.kotlin-academy.com
Twitter EN: @KtDotAcademy
Twitter PL: @ktdotacademyPL
FB: @KtDotAcademy
LinkedIn: @Kt. Academy

Best articles from 2021 from our blog & Happy New Year from Kt. Academy 🎆 was originally published in Kt. Academy on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

entries.title: Advent of Kotlin: Week 4
entries.author: Kasia Kt. Academy

content.value:
Hello Kotliners!

This is a special, 4-weeks edition of our newsletter. It will contain content with only one, special topic.
ℹ️ The answers to the whole game will be published next week! Enjoy! 😉

Welcome to the 4th week of the

Advent of Kotlin 🎄

How did you like our previous #AdventOfKotlin challenges?

Was it a piece of cake? 😏

*️⃣ We’d love to hear your thoughts and suggestions for this newsletter. Please share them with us by replying to this email 📩

And now…

here we go, good luck with the last one 👇

Advent of Kotlin: Week 4

Have fun and don’t forget to share your answers with us! 🎅

#AdventOfKotlin

We can’t wait to see who is gonna win 🏆

Thank you and see you next week!

Kt. Academy Team

www: kt.academy
Blog: blog.kotlin-academy.com
Twitter EN: @KtDotAcademy
Twitter PL: @ktdotacademyPL
FB: @KtDotAcademy
LinkedIn: @Kt. Academy

Advent of Kotlin: Week 4 🔥 was originally published in Kt. Academy on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.
